author: SpiderJusty
title: Stay Puft Lego Dimensions Review
review:
Before I start, I need to say that I am a huge fan of the original Ghostbusters movie which may have some bias towards this villain.

The minifigure is fantastic and is great for using for play areas, and my only real complaint is the Terror Dog is a little small for the detail, but that's really it.

If you can, BUY THIS SET.  It is worth every dollar to build and play with.

author: 8BrickMario
title: Choose...or ignore?
review:
I got this pack mostly to have the minifigure, but I was looking forward to playing around as him. How did that work out?

 

Parts

The pieces aren't too rate, but I think the horns and the three-toothed grey plates will be somewhat desirable.

Minifigure

The Stay-Puft Marshmallow Man, the accidental choice by Ray Stantz as to which form Gozer the Destroyer should take, is a great figure. The headpiece, which incorporates the collar and hat, is well molded and captures the unnervingly blank expression of Mr. Stay Puft rather well, and the hat and collar are painted well. It's a shame the scale was so small that they couldn't print "STAY PUFT" on his hat brim. His torso is very simple, only having the knot of his sailor's collar printed on it, and his legs are plain. Sure, he's vastly undersized and nowhere near as rotund, but he's a neat little minifigure to have. 

The completed model

The Terror Dog is rather serviceable, and while it may not be perfectly scaled or proportioned, I'd be fine including it in the HQ set. Its future builds don't look quite as impressive, but I'm just happy the first one can be taken out of context so easily.

Gameplay

I've already reviewed the Ghostbusters world he can grant access to, but yeah, if you don't have Venkman or Slimer, he'll do. 

Abilities-wise? He's not that great. He does have the ability to grow to double size, but it's on a time limit like everyone else, and it feels slightly disappointing that someone who is known for being huge can't stay huge. He's immune to toxic waste, and he can break through cracked walls, but honestly, the most fun thing about him is the animations, which stretch him out to imply a gooey marshmallow texture. The Terror Dog is a good enough form of transportation, and its later forms have fire breath and flight, if you need those. 

Overall

I don't think this pack is at all essential. But it's got a great minifigure and model for Ghostbusters fans, so if you really want them, have fun. Otherwise, it seems like a bit of a letdown...but hey, another monster is another monster, right?

author: Odeinoichus
title: There is no Dana, Only Zuul
review:
Set #71233 Stay Puft Fun Pack: LEGO Ghostbusters included even more elements in Dimensions and this is the only way to get a Minifigure Stay Puft, completely not to scale, but very well put together. The content in-game is also fairly interesting as you get to control a Terror Dog, but let’s get to the rest of the review.

Packaging

Typical Fun Pack packaging here with its uniform colouring and design choices. This one has some nice shots on the front and back of the toys in action with the digital in-game shots really proving that this thing is pretty awesome.

Parts

This set comes with a lot of grey elements, dark and light bley parts are used and there’s really nothing outstanding included here aside from a small smattering of Mixel joint elements.

Minifigures

Stay Puft: A very simple looking Minifigure he’s almost monochromatic, plain white legs, minimalistic torso print with the little red scarf, unique head piece includes sculpted neck covering and the hat perched jauntily on the side of his head. He has no accessories, no marshmallow bag or goo to toss at his enemies, but hey we can’t always have an accessory specific to the character.

The build

Terror Dog: This build is highly satisfying. I love the way they made such a horrifying beast into Lego form. It is both menacing looking and cute, and was immensely satisfying to build, each step layers onto the next to complete the model perfectly. It alone is worth the price of multiple copies of this set.

Terror Dog Destroyer: This build is actually similar to the Winged Monkey, it is built up onto the toy tag with criss-crossed legs, which makes the model slightly unstable when removed from the tag as it makes it harder to stand on its own. The model is pretty faithful to its digital counterpart though.

Soaring Terror Dog: This third and final build is a quick and easy bit of rearranging of parts to make a flying spectral beast with teeny tiny wings and an oversized head, makes it look like it should topple over. Still really fun to build though.

The completed model

Terror Dog & Alternate Builds: Each model uses the same parts in new configurations to complete the looks of the three separate creatures they’ve designed. The Terror Dog matches what we know of Zuul and his compatriot quite nicely, looking suitably menacing and quite enjoyable.

The Terror Dog Destroyer is a two-headed monstrosity which looks like someone spent too much time trying to imagine a horrible alternative to the original design. It’s spooky, menacing and impressive, but a bit mediocre as far as parts use is concerned due to taking some of the elements from the feet to make a second head. Off the toy tag he (or she) isn’t entirely fun since it doesn’t look nice as a separate toy.

The Soaring Terror Dog makes a one-legged horror that swoops down upon the Ghostbusters and spews flames from its mouth. It’s actually a solid model and looks great, definitely an improvement over the slightly messy looking second model.

The Digital Content

Adventure World: Stay Puft can also access the Ghostbusters Adventure World, supposedly a patch was included that allowed 80’s era figures access to the 2016 era Adventure World as well, I’ve never actually tried that, but it is meant to be a feature with Year Two. You can’t access any of the levels though so you’d still need Venkman and the 2016 Story Pack to unlock everything.

Character & Creature Abilities: Stay Puft can destroy Cracked LEGO Objects has Hazard Protection and the Big Transform ability. Which is a pretty limited number of abilities shared amongst a wide variety of characters.

The Terror Dog has the Guardian ability, not much else for the original model. Rebuild it into the Terror Dog Destroyer and you can now Dig and Destroy Silver LEGO Objects. The third build gives you a Special Weapon and the ability to fly, though you can’t interact with flight docks or flight cargo hooks, but you can compete in flying races while riding an evil spectral Class 5 creature.

Overall opinion

I’d recommend picking this up mostly for fans of Ghostbusters, the digital content isn’t enough to warrant purchase for game play, but for collectors who want more Ghostbuster elements to display in their collection it’s a great pack. The models and figures look better, definitely recommend it more as a toy rather than a toy to life character.
